## Rank

<br>


<font size="5" color="blue"> What is the rank of the matrix A ? </font>


<br>

$$A \ = \ \begin{bmatrix} 	1&2&3&4\\ -1&0&1&3\\ 0&1&-2&1 \\5&4&-2&-3		\end{bmatrix}$$
<br>


If a square matrix has a determinant, then we immediately know that no row can be eliminated
as being linearly dependent on any other row or linear combination of rows.

<br>


```{r matrix_a_determinant}


a<-matrix(c(1, 2, 3, 4, -1, 0, 1, 3,0, 1, -2, 1,5, 4, -2, -3), byrow = TRUE, ncol = 4)
det(a)


```


<br>

So in this case, we know that A is full rank, its rank is 4.



```{r matrix_a_rank}

Matrix::rankMatrix(a)[1]

```






<br>
<font size="5" color="blue">
Given an mxn matrix where m > n, what can be the maximum rank? The minimum rank, assuming that the matrix is non-zero?
</font>

<br>

The maximum rank of m rows, is m. That would be when n=m, meaning you have enough variables and independent equations
to find the intersection all n coefficients.

<br>

The minimum is 1, which means you only have 1 independent equation.

<br>

<font size="5" color="blue">What is the rank of matrix B?</font>

<br>


$$A \ = \ \begin{bmatrix} 	1&2&1\\ 3&6&3\\ 2&4&2		\end{bmatrix}$$
<br>
One can see pretty easily that all 3 are dependent so the rank is 1 and the determinent is 0
<br>

```{r matrix_rank}

a<-matrix(c(1, 2, 1, 3, 6, 3, 2, 4,2), byrow = TRUE, ncol = 3)
det(a)

Matrix::rankMatrix(a)[1]

```

<br>

<br>

We can double check our work.

<br>

$$\lambda \ = 6$$

<br>

```{r eigen1}

a<-matrix(c(1, 2, 3, 0, 4, 5, 0, 0,6), byrow = TRUE, ncol = 3)

b<-c(8/5, 5/2,1)
a %*% b

6 * b   



```


<br>

$$\lambda \ = 4$$

<br>

```{r eigen2}

a<-matrix(c(1, 2, 3, 0, 4, 5, 0, 0,6), byrow = TRUE, ncol = 3)

b<-c(1, 3/2,0)
a %*% b

4 * b   



```

<br>



$$\lambda \ = 1$$

<br>

```{r eigen3}

a<-matrix(c(1, 2, 3, 0, 4, 5, 0, 0,6), byrow = TRUE, ncol = 3)

b<-c(1, 0,0)
a %*% b
1 * b   



```
